results.description:
This group is dedicated exclusively to novels. Please read the Novel Group Intro and FAQ before attending.  Be prepared to read back through previous chapters of a novel-in-progress before committing to this group.

HOW MEMBERS SUBMIT NOVEL SECTIONS:



Email your submission to [masked] 

SUBJECT: The Title of the group you're submitting to and your name. EXAMPLE: Cam's Novel Group December 8th, Spidercam
MESSAGE: Name, Title, Word Count, any additional info. EXAMPLE: Spidercam, Glory Chapter 2, 7,000 words. This is a rewrite.
Send to [masked]

Attach your document. RTF and DOC are preferred. Please, NO PDF's   


What to Expect: Nine days before the meeting you will receive an email from Meetup with links to download each story for critique from our Dropbox account. Click on the link and download the stories.

Please make sure your manuscript is properly formatted. See our Procedures, located under the Pages tab, for guidelines and an example, as well as advice for a constructive critique. Having manuscripts already formatted makes the critiquing process easier.


Most of the meeting will be spent critiquing work of group members. There is a structure in place to make sure the critiques are as helpful as possible for everyone involved, and that the writers leave with a clear idea of what to do with their stories next. You can find advice about how to give a critique here.

We'll also spend some time talking about writing, sharing news and information, and getting to know one another. It's always easier to take constructive criticism from someone you know, so the social element of the group is as important as the work itself!

results.description:
PLEASE READ THE INFORMATION BELOW CAREFULLY, ESPECIALLY THE BOLD TYPE.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO".  THERE IS NO NEED TO POST WHY YOU CAN'T MAKE THE EVENT. 

HAVE EXTRA LAYERS OF CLOTHING. PLEASE DRESS PROPERLY FOR THE EARLY COOL SPRING CONDITIONS. BECAUSE LOWER MANHATTAN IS SURROUNDED BY WATER, IT IS USUALLY COOLER DOWN THERE.

I also scheduled this same walk on Saturday, March 5th.

This is a sociable walk along a very scenic route filled with interesting places. I will comment on some things (the architecture and social history of some of the buildings) along the way, but you will have plenty of time to socialize with others. We will be stopping at a number of points of interest. (IF YOU DON'T LIKE THIS STOPPING, THEN THIS WALK IS NOT GOOD FOR YOU.) This walk is about 2 1/2 miles. 

If you have any questions for me, please contact me through my private Meetup inbox. The organizer for this Meetup event is John (the Event Host) who is listed on the top of the "going list" with a photo. 

Description: In Tribeca, we'll discuss industrial architecture/artifacts; the humanitarian Cocoanut King; the House of Relief's unusual way to treat patients; and the lost art of whalebone cutting. Later in the Civic Center area, we'll talk about the profitable business of corrupt politicians; skyscrapers erected by mighty corporations; a sculptor who has angered people from the late 19th century to the present; how someone once got a decent-paying job at a dime museum on the Bowery; and so on.


Cost: The cost of this event is $2 per person, which is paid at the start of the walk. This is for the organizer's Meetup preparation costs and fees.

Meeting Time/Place: The meeting time is (after lunch) 2:00 PM. The meeting place is outside of the entrance to Barnes and Noble Bookstore/Bed, Bath & Beyond, which are located at 97 Warren Street, between Greenwich Street and West Street. Before the walk, restrooms are available in Barnes & Noble Bookstore or Bed, Bath & Beyond. During the walk, there will be limited places to stop for a restroom.

Transportation: Take the 1, 2, or 3 subway train to Chambers St (about 2 blocks away) or the A or C subway train to Chambers St (about 3 blocks away).

Finishing Time/Place: The walk will finish between 4:30 PM and 4:45 PM at Fulton Street and Broadway. This is near the Fulton Street subway station (a major transportation hub) that has a number of subway lines.

Rainy weather or other bad weather conditions will cancel this walk. Therefore, if it is rainy weather or other bad weather conditions or the forecast is for rainy weather or other bad weather conditions, I will post a cancellation notice on Sunday morning (before (9:00 AM). This walk will only happen in good weather conditions. If I don't post a cancellation notice, I plan to be at the meeting place. If I do cancel the walk, I will also post a cancellation notice on the Discussion Board.

Located in New England, the Walter Baker & Company's regional headquarters was in the Lower West Side (Tribeca). (Sources Overland Monthly Magazine, January, 1919/The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, January 23, 1908)

The words “root beer” initially caused outrage among the 19th century Temperance Movement, but root beer firms began to advertise root beer as the “temperance drink,” arguing that it had no alcohol and was a great alternative to alcoholic beverages or contaminated water. Knapp's Root Beer Extract Company was located in the Lower West Side (Tribeca). (Sources The Evening World, July 18, 1893/The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, May 16, 1891)

results.description:
This month's book is The Traitor Baru Cormorant by Seth Dickinson.

Tomorrow, on the beach, Baru Cormorant will look up from the sand of her home and see red sails on the horizon.

The Empire of Masks is coming, armed with coin and ink, doctrine and compass, soap and lies. They'll conquer Baru’s island, rewrite her culture, criminalize her customs, and dispose of one of her fathers. But Baru is patient. She'll swallow her hate, prove her talent, and join the Masquerade. She will learn the secrets of empire. She’ll be exactly what they need. And she'll claw her way high enough up the rungs of power to set her people free.

In a final test of her loyalty, the Masquerade will send Baru to bring order to distant Aurdwynn, a snakepit of rebels, informants, and seditious dukes. Aurdwynn kills everyone who tries to rule it. To survive, Baru will need to untangle this land’s intricate web of treachery - and conceal her attraction to the dangerously fascinating Duchess Tain Hu.

But Baru is a savant in games of power, as ruthless in her tactics as she is fixated on her goals. In the calculus of her schemes, all ledgers must be balanced, and the price of liberation paid in full.

This book is available from various sellers, via Goodreads.

* * *


IMPORTANT RSVP POLICY

If you RSVP and find you cannot make it, please change your RSVP so that we are not waiting for you. Please change it no less than two hours before the scheduled meeting time. If you RSVP and do not show, you will have to pay $10 when you attend your next event. This is to prevent those on the waiting list from missing out on an event.

The RSVP policy is the same as for the general meetup. Please see the entire policy here:
http://www.meetup.com/NYSciFi-Fantasy/pages/Membership_Policy/


* * *


Questions and answers!

Where will we be meeting?

We will be meeting at the Citigroup Atrium.

There's an entrance at 53rd and Lexington Avenue off the 53rd and Lex subway stop. You have to go down the steps; the subway station will be on your right and the Atrium will be straight in front of you. The doors are labeled.

There is a Barnes and Noble (with a Starbucks inside) on the next level up at 54th and 3rd. If you enter through the B&N, you will need to go through B&N (up a few steps from the entrance), past the NOOK display to the glass doors and down the escalator to the atrium.

There is a lift down the stairs on the right side of the corridor as you're coming from the fountain.

There's also free wi-fi and restrooms if you need them.

How will I recognize the group when I get there?

We're generally pretty easy for newcomers to recognize--if in doubt, look for paper copies of the book on tables, or a group of excited-looking people with lots of electronic reading devices. We'll try to recognize you from your picture; if in doubt, feel free to walk up and ask people!

Do I need to finish the whole book?

Nope! You're welcome to come either way. However, the whole book is fair game for discussion, including the ending!

How are the books chosen?

We try to select the next book and date of the meetup after we're finished discussing the book. We sometimes do this by poll, selected from the attendees' suggestions -- if so, the attendees will be invited to vote on the website by email. Sometimes we'll all jump on an appealing suggestion, or sometimes I'll get bored of posting polls and just pick one by fiat.

What books has the club read in the past?

We've compiled a list. (Thanks to Sarah for compiling this for us!)

I have another question!

You're welcome to message me through the website, or comment here. 

Thanks for signing up, and I hope to see you there!

Also, join our Goodreads group!

http://www.goodreads.com/group/show/57070.NY_Fantasy_Book_Club
results.name: Fantasy Book Club: The Traitor Baru Cormorant by Seth Dickinson

results.description:
REGISTER HERE

Join us for a special panel event on long form photojournalism with 3 amazing Pulitzer Center grantees: Daniella Zalcman, Jake Naughton, and Alice Proujansky! They'll discuss their projects, applying and working on grants, their successes working with the Pulitzer Center, and much more! 

Daniella Zalcman is an award-winning photojournalist based in London and New York. Her work has been published in The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times, TIME, Sports Illustrated, and CNN, among others. She is a multiple grantee of the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting. Her photographs have been exhibited throughout the U.S. and Europe and are part of the permanent collection of the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. She graduated from Columbia University in 2009 with a degree in architecture

Jake Naughton is a visual journalist working on stories about LGBT and immigration issues, but mostly he's just in search of the sublime. He is a frequent contributor to The New York Times, and additional clients include Al Jazeera America, Highline, VICE Magazine and The MasterCard Foundation. His work has been recognized and supported by American Photography, POYI, NPPA and the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting, and he is a founding member of the creative cooperative Black Box.

Alice Proujansky is a documentary photographer covering women and labor: birth, work, motherhood and identity. She has been photographing Birth Culture since 2006, and Women's Work since 2013. Her work has been published by New York Magazine, the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, the Nation, The New Republic, CBS, the Guardian, Harpers and others. She has received support from the Magnum Foundation, the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting, the Solutions Journalism Network and the Economic Hardship Reporting Project, and was selected for the Review Santa Fe 2014 and the New York Portfolio Review 2016. In addition to her documentary work, Alice has taught photography to at-risk young people and their teachers since 2002 and currently coordinates educational partnerships for On Sight, Aperture’s community programs initiative.

The panel will be mkoderted by photo editor Andrea Wise. 


Andrea Wise is curently a photo editor for ViewFind.com, a photojournalism startup aimed at bringing visual stories to a mass audience while helping photojournalists monetize their archives and get commissions. She earned her M.S. in Photography from Syracuse University where she was an Instructional Associate teaching photography and multimedia production to undergraduate and graduate students, as well as Graduate Assistant to Mike Davis, Chair of the Alexia Foundation for World Peace. Her work has been recognized by The National Press Photographers Association and College Photographer of the Year. She's an alum of Eddie Adams Workshop XXVI, The Kalish Visual Editing Workshop, and The Mountain Workshops. AndreaWise.com
results.name: Pulitzer Center Grantee Panel | Long Form Photojournalism

results.description:
Click the link below to purchase a ticket to this event:


http://www.bigmaven.com/experience/ny-adventure-club-special-access-tour-the-morris-jumel-mansion/

Join New York Adventure Club for a special access tour at the Morris-Jumel Mansion, Manhattan’s oldest residence (1765) that has witnessed the evolution of northern Manhattan from rural countryside to a dynamic multicultural community.

Our experience will include:

• A tour throughout the mansion

• A discussion around the house's role in the American Revolution

• An exclusive preview of artifacts from the upcoming September 2016 exhibit, "Encamped on the Heights," which focuses on the military strategy during the American Revolution

• Artifacts that haven't been seen by the public for over 100 years.

• The docent's personal stories from when the Queen of England visited the Mansion in 1976

After the tour, we'll head to a local eatery for some food and drinks!
results.name: NY Adventure Club: Special Access Tour @ the Morris-Jumel Mansion

results.description:
Spring has sprung in Central Park! This tour is specifically designed for people who live, work and play in the New York Area and who are members and friends of CRC and Holy Trinity.  It is our goal to open your eyes to historical sites and info that you may walk past every day!  Our tours are fun ways to learn about the city while socializing with other fun people from our group. It is amazing that Manhattan, which was once known as the Island of Rolling Hills, has transformed into the Concrete Canyon it is today.  Along the way your professional guide will share historical facts and show you a photographic history that will amaze you.  Be a tourist in your own city and sign up today!


Your guide will share with you the history of the park from its heyday to decline and then rebirth. He will show you amazing pictures  from before the park was there to vintage shots from the late 18 and 1900's.  You will learn of it's construction, design, special secrets and more as the sun shines on a  spring day.

The tour lasts about 90 minutes and following the walk you can join us for the CRC New Members Welcome Meeting and 5:30 mass


In case or rain and the tour is canceled we will email you.

Please pay $15 when you arrive.  100% of the proceeds will be used towards our Dominican Republic Mission trip (which begins the next day!)
results.name: Private Central Park Spring History Walk to Benefit The Dominican Mission Trip

A REMINDER Note to all STSANY actors - beginners, intermediate or advanced:

The Retirees Monologues: Like a "Master Class" in Acting:

We encourage you to attend this event: You will learn a lot about acting, how to write and/or present monologues, stage presentation, etc., for a live audience. 50 attendees have already  RSVPd - many from other meetup groups. The Ellington seats about 70 people. You can RSVP up 'till the performance.

Don't miss this FREE opportunity to learn and enjoy an afternoon of monologues.

Details:

Dear STSANY members and friends,

You are invited to attend a FREE performance of The Retiree Monologues by The Rainbow Players. 

The Retiree Monologues is a group of ten monologues about the joys, tribulations, and challenges of the retirement experience.  Former teachers from the United Federation of Teachers (UFT) first wrote their pieces in a writing workshop and then honed their performances under the auspices of the UFT Players.  Some of the monologues take up topics such as making the big decision to retire and losses and gains. A Q & A follows their performance. If any of you have questions or anecdotes you'd like to share, share away!


Guess what? Our co-organizer, Lourdes Ayala, will be performing with The Rainbow Players! Let's come out in support of her and the other talented actors. They have performed the monologues in several venues around the City, and have received much enthusiasm and praise from their audiences.

Photo: Lourdes Ayala

We hope to see you on April 10. Bring your friends and family to this enjoyable and unusual event.

Cheers,

Anna

If you are a lover of chamber music, you won't want to miss this event! A CelloPointe concert is unique as it alternates musical interludes, at the highest level, with choreographed pieces. This year are very excited to present part of the Goldberg Variations for string trio with the wonderful musicians; Ida Kavafian, Steven Tenenbom and Peter Wiley. This will be choreographed by Balanchine ballerina, Deborah Wingert. We are also excited to present Jessica Lee on violin. Not only will she play the Prokofiev duet with her teacher, Ida but we are also playing movements of string quartets by Ravel, Verdi and Dvorak. Peter Wiley, cellist, will play a choreographed piece to the Faure Elegy. Also on the program is the Borodin string trio, choreographed by Elena Comendador. CelloPointe is in rehearsal for this program and I think it will be our best concert yet! Tickets with this code are available online only. We feel that anybody interested in chamber music will enjoy this concert!

results.description:
****READ THIS FIRST || Parade Grounds Game Standards ****

Meet on field 8!!!

The game is scheduled to start at 3:30. We typically start 15-30 minutes after 3:30. Your RSVP is good if you come on time. If you come after teams are divided then you run the risk of not playing. Those who have RSVP’ed get first preference to play (This does not apply to anyone on the waiting list). Also, please  Un-RSVP if you will not be attending. That gives other people a chance to play.

Rules and guidelines:

These games are geared towards advanced to intermediate players.

Teams are divided by two team captains (captains pick players in turns in an attempt to keep teams balanced and competitive)

Physical play is allowed as long as it isn't overly aggressive or dirty.

Slide tackles are allowed only to block a shot on goal or to intercept a pass  NO slide tackling on a player with the ball.

Ball hogging is absolutely not tolerated 

Keep in mind as we don't have permit, we need to be flexible.

results.description:
NON-COMPETITIVE CO-ED SOCCER GAMES @ Frederick Douglass Playground


                                 Check our Facebook page:

              facebook.com/ManhattanInternationalCoedSoccer 

                          NO CLEATS OR PLASTIC STUDS ALLOWED

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=41MNlrZf-MY

GAME DESCRIPTION:

Our games are for all levels and people that prefer to play a non-competitive game of soccer, break a sweat while exercising running up and down the field with the ball and all this happening in a very laid-back and non-judgmental environment. Please, arrive 10 minutes before the game so we can get the teams set up.

Game Format:

We'll play three simultaneous games of 7 on 7, with small goals. There will be 6 teams on the field and we will play three games, 30 minutes/game. Every 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play against different team. Please check our meetup message board on Saturday night or before 9:00 am on Sunday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

RULES OF THE GAME:

1-First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field!

2-Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.

3-No power shots allowed.

4-If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.

5-If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.


6-Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game.

Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Please check our meetup message board on Saturday night or before 12:00 PM on Saturday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

Location:

Frederick Douglass Playground


Take the 1,2 or 3 RED Line Train to 96th street Station and walk 4 blocks down, to 101st Street and Amsterdam Ave. or the 1 RED Line Train to 103rd Street Station and walk 1 block.

Call me if you can’t find the field - [masked] Manny S. 

What to bring with you:

A pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes(No CLEATS), shin guards (recommended) and lots of water. There is a water fountain next to the park if you need extra water.

Fee:

You will be asked to pay $9.50 when you RSVP. This $9.50 is used to pay for, facilities permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, goals, cones, soccer balls etc.

Refunds & Weather Policy:

Refunds will be issued if the RSVP is changed by Wednesday before 12.00PM or if the game is cancelled. The game can be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe like heavy rain, snow or thunder.

After the game we'll head to Royale for brunch and a Pint or Two:

                                       Lion’s Head Tavern 

                                     995 Amsterdam Ave

                                      New York, NY 10025

                                           (212)[masked]

PARTICIPATING IN MANHATTAN-INTERNATIONAL-COED-SOCCER ACTIVITIES AGREEMENT:

I certify that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore, I, individually, hereby release and discharge, Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer Organizer and Assistant Organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer programs or activities. Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer Organizer and its Assistant Organizers reserve the right to take and utilize photographs, video, or any type of recording of participating person while engaged in our or associated activities. I consent to Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer use the photograph, video, or recording of me, for advertising, promotional, or related purposes, and waive all rights to compensation and other rights which may arise as a result.

results.description:
Hello Everyone:

It's the event of the year for us!  Zack Schulman is hosting the annual Ferment! Ferment! party.  This annual gathering of fermentation enthusiasts provided the inspiration for our Meet-Up. 


For anyone who'd like to head in to the event together, let's plan to meet out front at 4pm sharp. If you can't make it at 4pm, don't worry about missing us. The building is fairly small so we should be able to find each other inside.

For other details, see Zack's description below:

Gather for a celebration of homemade fermented food & drink!

Fermentation is everywhere and it deserves our love and attention. The goal of Ferment! Ferment! is to encourage home fermentation, and to come together to enjoy and share our experiences making these foods. In a world of fetishization of the food professional, let’s celebrate the amateur fermenter. Think of this as not only a party, but also an informal tasting.

Do you make something special with your homemade ferments? Maybe you concoct a unique mustard from your own vinegar, or cook up a satisfying soup from your own miso, or perhaps you incorporate home-aged cheese into a delicious dish. How about a funky kraut or fiery kimchi! If so, this is your opportunity to share these types of things.

The guidelines are simple: bring a homemade fermented food or drink or something made with a homemade ferment to share. If you’re unsure if it’s fermented, just drop me a line and ask. Alternatively (or additionally) bring a culture/starter to swap at the culture exchange table.

There will also be a few workshops going on throughout the afternoon and evening. We have a bunch of open spots, so if you’ve got skills and you’d like to share, let me know; there are modest stipends available for workshop facilitators.

RSVPs to Zack at z[dot]schulman[at]gmail[dot]com requested. Please share this with anyone who might be interested.

Sunday, April 10
4pm to 8pm

Brooklyn Free School
372 Clinton Ave (between Greene & Lafayette)
Brooklyn, NY 11238

This event is free, but we’ll pass the hat to support our generous hosts.
results.name: Ferment!  Ferment! Zack Schulman's Annual Fermentation Party!

results.description:
Since 1997, the CRC has been planning activities at Holy Trinity.  The group originally was meant for "Young Adults" ages 20's and 30's but as the years passed we realized that we could not exclude or kick out our friends who were still important members of our community once they turned 40!  Today the CRC is an all inclusive group for those who are Young Adults in their hearts and minds.  You will find plenty of people in your peer groups and beyond.

On Sunday , we are going to invite all who want to find out more about the group and how to get involved for a short and informal gathering prior to the 5:30 mass at Holy Trinity.  Current and past CRC Council members will be on hand to share experiences and take you ideas on things that the group can do.

Following the meeting the group will go to mass together (we'll have reserved seating) Following mass we have a party in the Murphy Center


Do I need to be a member of Holy Trinity to participate?  No, our members come from all over the tri state area.

What is the age limit?  There really is none (do you think Jesus would be that exclusive!) You will find most people are 20's - 40's and some 50's.  It is more about being Young at Heart.

What does the group focus on?  Mainly social activities and community service events.  We will also have spiritual activities from time to time.

If I can't make the meeting how can I get involved?  Try to come for the party afterwards or to any Sunday evening gathering.
results.name: New & Existing Members Welcome Meeting

results.description:
All you love is gone. The Stilt-Sands, a floating city you have called home since birth, was torn to pieces before your eyes. Ensorcelled before the disaster, you could do nothing to save anyone but yourself, watching the horror as if it were nothing but a bad dream.

Your refuge is the Salty Cormorant, an odd amalgamation of pirate and Navy vessel. There, you came fully back to your senses, and are filled with nothing but rage and pain. And you aren’t the only one. You, and the other 300 survivors, have been robbed of home and health, and there are others who would see it righted, or avenged. You are told that you sail for Precipice Port. A fortnight cannot pass soon enough. Until then, you will find out everything the crew of this strange ship knows, to find some clue about the terrible beast He. However, you are not alone in this pursuit. The evil that trapped your minds has followed you, and it is not done with you yet. 

Stilt-Sand Survivors is the first chapter in the new WildPig Exclusive Campaign "Vengeance at Sea" by Noah Anderson, set in the “Ten Isles” setting developed by Noah Anderson in association with the WildPig community. All players are welcome. Characters are 1st level, with a limit of 8 players per session. There will be time for character creation a half-hour before the first session. Seats are limited, so please register ahead of time.
results.name: D&D 5E: Vengeance at Sea Chapter 1 - Stilt-Sand Survivors

results.description:
Most people think they should give to charity, and don't really get around to giving, or if they do, don't give much.  But it's not just the quantity of giving that counts, the quality of giving is important.

Here's a story of good intentions gone bad: How not to donate money.

Charity Navigator is a popular website to evaluate the quality of charities.  Their main criterion is "What percent of their budget goes to administrative and fundraising costs, versus the actual charity work?".  Charities with the lowest administrative and fundraising burdens are considered the "best".

But this analysis is flawed.  It's like saying the animal whose brain consists of the lowest proportion of the animal's whole body weight is the "best" animal.

Shouldn't charities engage in research to see how effective their efforts are?  But Charity Navigator will punish them for any such efforts.  And another question is: how much good does the activity of the charity actually accomplish?

GiveWell is another, more sophisticated website.  They review many charities, but only recommend less than a dozen of the best.  To make it to the top, a charity must be evidence-backed, that is they do research to verify that they are accomplishing their objectives.

Conservatives give more to charity than liberals, though a lot of that is religious giving.  Ideologically, conservatives are more likely to believe that churches and private charity should play a key role in the social safety net, while liberals will tend to limit their charitable actions to voting for a generous government-funded safety net.  Conservative atheists, however, donate the least of all.

At this meeting, we will talk about which charities are best to give to, and our experiences with giving.

This event is co-listed with the Fans of Capitalism meetup.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be in the front, and I'll have a sign on the table.  I look like my picture, plus a mustache.
results.name: Competent Philanthropy & Effective Altruism

results.description:
UPDATE: The books are in at the Astoria Bookshop. Stop by and pick up a copy.

Come join Mindful Astoria for our April Book Club selection: Herman Hesse's classic tale of journeying to spiritual self-discovery, Siddhartha.

In the book, Siddhartha, a young man, leaves his family for a contemplative life, then, restless, discards it for one of the flesh. He conceives a son, but bored and sickened by lust and greed, moves on again. Near despair, Siddhartha comes to a river where he hears a unique sound. This sound signals the true beginning of his life—the beginning of suffering, rejection, peace, and, finally, wisdom.

Siddhartha is set during the time of the Gautama Buddha. The word Siddhartha is made up of two words in the Sanskrit language, siddha (achieved) + artha (what was searched for), which together means “he who has found meaning (of existence)” or “he who has attained his goals.” In fact, the Buddha’s own name before his renunciation was Siddhartha Gautama, Prince of Kapilvastu. In this book, the Buddha is referred to as “Gotama.”


Come join us for a discussion of this rewarding tale.

There will be a very brief guided mindfulness meditation during this meeting. No prior meditation experience necessary.


The Astoria Bookshop will be offering a 10% discount for anyone in our group who purchases the selection through them.

The edition we are featuring is the from the beautiful Penguin Drop Caps series which "...is a great example of the power of design. Each cover is foil-stamped with a cleverly illustrated letterform that reveals an element of the story. The complete set forms a rainbow spectrum prettier than anything else on your bookshelf." —Rex Bonomelli, The New York Times


This event is free, but please consider buying the book through the Astoria Bookshop to support local business and thank them for giving us the space to meet.

Note: you do not have to have read the entire book to attend. Also, you do not have to read the featured edition. There have been many different editions of the novel printed through the years.
results.name: Book Discussion at the Astoria Bookshop: SIDDHARTHA

results.description:
Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

Meet other members for a brief happy hour mingle while guests arrive.  Once everyone has checked-in you'll be seated for your series of four minute "mini-dates." On your dating card that you receive at check-in, you'll select who you wish to see again. You can choose Dating or Friendship as your preferred connection.

We will collect everyone's dating cards at the end of the event and email you your mutual matches within 48 hours.

While this event is geared towards helping people meet potential romantic matches, you can also mingle with all the guests and find new friends as well.

On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24  - PAY IN ADVANCE ONLY - WE DO NOT ACCEPT PAYMENT AT DOOR

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: https://2016atwysnycspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.


OUR METHOD:

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's  more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. 

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

results.description:
Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

Meet other members for a brief happy hour mingle while guests arrive.  Once everyone has checked-in you'll be seated for your series of four minute "mini-dates." On your dating card that you receive at check-in, you'll select who you wish to see again. You can choose Dating or Friendship as your preferred connection.

We will collect everyone's dating cards at the end of the event and email you your mutual matches within 48 hours.

While this event is geared towards helping people meet potential romantic matches, you can also mingle with all the guests and find new friends as well.

On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24  - PAY IN ADVANCE ONLY - WE DO NOT ACCEPT PAYMENT AT DOOR

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: https://2016atwysnycspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.


OUR METHOD:

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's  more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. 

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

results.description:
Back to Spain, to explore a region that is less well known than the subregions within it—Castilla y León. 

Castilla y León is the largest of Spain’s 17 administrative regions and covers the northern half of the central Iberian plateau.  The region’s agriculture is largely focused on grains, but viticulture has taken place here for a couple of millennia.  The climate is very much continental—hot summers, cold winters, sharp daily temperature shifts during the growing season.  A coastal mountain range, the Cordillera Cantábrica, prevents any maritime influence.  Rainfall is low, soils are mostly thin and poor, with more clay and mineral around the rivers that flow through the area.  And the region’s most prestigious winegrowing districts are in the Duero Valley, near the river that becomes the Douro on the other side of the Portuguese border.  This is Tempranillo country, although the grape is known locally as Tinto Fino, Tinto del Pais, or Tinto de Toro.

We’ll be trying wines from six appellations.

Rueda:  This is one of the few Spanish wine regions that are best known for superior white wines.  Sherry-like fortified wines once dominated here, based on the Palomino grape, but in the 1970s, Rioja’s Bodegas Marques de Riscal saw the potential for dry unfortified white wines using the aromatic, fruity varietal Verdejo, which now accounts for 90 percent of production.  Cool nights help preserve the wine’s fresh acidity in this otherwise hot region.  Much of the Verdejo is unoaked, preserving the wine’s fruit-forward qualities, but some producers are now employing barrel fermentation.  We’ll be trying two Rueda Verdejos, one unoaked and made from an almost-extinct Verdejo clone, and a notably oaky barrel-fermented example.  It will be interesting to see which production method better complements the grape’s qualities. 

Toro:  Just west of Rueda and 40 miles east of the Portuguese border lies Toro, named after a town of the same name.  It seems appropriate that the local wines, powerful reds based on the local Tempranillo strain, Tinta de Toro, call to mind the image of a bull.  The hot continental climate means that these grapes achieve high potential alcohol, so local authorities put a 15 percent cap on alcohol content for Toro wines.  The prestige of the region has been enhanced by investment by well-known winemakers from outside the area, such as Ribera del Duero’s Vega Sicilia.  We’ll be trying a Toro made by a former Vega Sicilia winemaker from old-vines ungrafted Tinta de Toro.  Judicious use of French oak preserves the wine’s elegance and character. 

Tierra del Vino de Zamora:  West of Toro lies Tierra del Vino de Zamora, a new appellation that acquired DO status in 2008.  It shares the climatic characteristics of Toro, but grows a greater variety of grapes—Malvasia, Godello, Verdejo, Tempranillo, Garnacha, and Cabernet Sauvignon, among others.  Nevertheless, Tempranillo still dominates.  The most prestigious maker in the region is Bodega Viñas del Cenit, and we will be trying their 2009 Via Cenit, made organically with old-vines Tempranillo (some over 100 years old), and matured in French oak.

Cigales: East of Toro lies Cigales, another relatively new appellation that lies at a higher altitude than its western neighbor.  This is a relatively undeveloped region, which has the advantage of preserving traditional viticultural methods and old vines.  Tempranillo (aka Tinta del Pais) dominates.  We’ll be trying a wine made by Rioja’s Baron de Ley at their Cigales winery, Finca Museum, where their goal is to make high-quality, value-priced wines from old-vines Tempranillo.

Ribera del Duero:  This is the most important and prestigious region within Castilla y León.  A relatively young DO (established in 1982), it now rivals Rioja as the most prestigious producer of Spanish red wines.  As the name suggests, the region straddles the Duero River, which provides a much-needed water supply and a limestone, chalk, and clay topsoil that adds complexity to the wines.  The star producer of the region is Vega Sicilia, whose flagship Unico wine is like the Spanish equivalent of a Bordeaux first growth.  Tempranillo must make up at least 75 percent of Ribera del Duero wine, with Bordeaux varietals usually used for blending.  Our Ribera del Duero comes from Hacienda Monasterio, where the resident winemaker is Danish enologist Peter Sisseck, who founded Pingus, another benchmark wine for the region.  Hacienda Monasterio represents unusual value for top-quality Ribera del Duero.

Sardon del Duero:  This is a contiguous region to the west of Ribera del Duero that shares the same geographic and climatic conditions.  The biggest name in the region is Abadia Retuerta, an ultramodern winery that maintains high quality standards for its Tempranillo wines despite large-volume production.  We’ll be trying their 2009 Selección Especial. 


We'll be meeting at Morton's Steakhouse in White Plains, which is BYOB on Sunday.  The reservationist was unaware of this policy—we might be the first to take advantage of it!  The Tempranillos should make a great match with a good steak.

http://www.mortons.com/whiteplains/#_=_

2014 Javier Sanz V Malcorta (Rueda)  $23

Wine Advocate 90 – Produced with an old Verdejo clone called “malcorta,” the 2014 V Malcorta has some tropical aromas of pineapple intermixed with more serious aromas of hay and straw, over a core of white fruit. The palate is intense with a combination of pineapple and leesy flavors, as it was matured in contact with the lees with bâttonage for some four months before bottling.

2011 Naia Naiades (Rueda)  $26

Jancis Robinson 16/20 – Creamy, rich, super-smooth. Good persistence and fruit purity, though quite reliant on caramel oak for complexity.

2011 Bodegas y Viñedos Maurodos San Roman (Toro)  $30

Wine Advocate 92 – The 2011 San Roman, is year in, year out, one of the most reliable wines of the appellation, pure Tempranillo (locally known as Tinta de Toro), the fruit from over 35-year-old, ungrafted and head-pruned vineyards planted on sandy, stony soils rich in clay in different villages across the Toro appellation. The wine aged for two years in French and American oak barrels, 80% of which were new. It’s an earthy wine with plenty of dark aromas of peat, fountain pen ink, graphite, and tar, with very ripe fruit, black and blue berries. The palate is quite full-bodied, with abundant but fine tannins and enough acidity and persistence. A Toro with character.

Wine Spectator 93 – Black plum, coffee, and mineral notes show depth and richness in this plush, firm red, with plenty of structure. Balanced and harmonious, ending with an alluring floral finish.

2009 Viñas del Cenit Via Cenit (Tierra del Vino de Zamora)  $30

Wine Advocate 91 – 100% Tempranillo.  The 2009 Via Cenit spent 12 months in French oak. It is purple/black in color with an impressive aromatic display of pain grillé, pencil lead, violets, incense, and blackberry. Full-bodied, structured, dense, and mouth-filling, it has the stuffing to evolve for 3-4 years and will provide pleasure through 2024 if not longer. Savory, ripe, and lengthy, it admirably reflects the superb conditions presented by the 2009 vintage.

2010 Bodegas Museum Vinea Tempranillo Crianza (Cigales)  $16

Wine Advocate 88 – The 2010 Vinea Tempranillo Crianza sees 15 months in oak barrel (60% American and 40% French) and is bottled unfiltered. It offers a generous, clean, sumptuous bouquet of dark plum, blueberry, mulberry, and mocha that displays good intensity. The palate is medium bodied with a soft, rounded entry. There is decent weight here for a Crianza, but it never tries to be overly ambitious. Rather, it aims for the “drinkability jugular” with its soft, caressing tannins and rich dark plum and mocha-tinged finish. This is well-crafted and epitomizes the kind of Spanish wine that gets finished to the bottom of the bottle.

2009 Abadia Retuerta Selección Especial (Sardón del Duero)  $32

Wine Advocate 90 – In terms of value for money, I would head straight to the 2009 Seleccion Especial, a blend of 75% Tempranillo, 15% Cabernet Sauvignon and 10% Syrah. It has a rounded, iodine-tinged bouquet with great purity and panache, the oak seamlessly integrated with scents of black coffee developing over time. The palate is medium-bodied with a fleshy texture, crisp acidity and very fine tannins. It has a velvety, caressing texture with blackberry, cassis and espresso towards the precise, supple finish. This is an accomplished, flavor-packed wine that should repay a few month’s cellaring. Drink now 2013-2018.

Tanzer 90 – (75% tempranillo, 15% cabernet sauvignon and 10% syrah, aged for 18 months in French and American oak):  Deep ruby.  Aromas and flavors of cherry compote, vanilla, mocha and tar, with smoke and floral overtones.  Lush and open-knit, finishing with punch and pliant tannins.  This wine is approachable now, with a little air.  

2010 Hacienda Monasterio Reserva (Ribera del Duero)  $64

Wine Advocate 95 – The 2010 Reserva contains 20% Cabernet Sauvignon from selected plots from their slope vineyards planted 25 years ago on chalk-rich soils that fermented with indigenous yeasts. 2010 was a near-perfect growing season, producing wines that are both powerful and fresh and that should have a long life in bottle. The nose is fragrant and elegant, mixing notes of red and black fruit with a sense of extreme harmony. Very showy. As much as it’s elegant it also feels powerful and serious, quite Ribera, with good typicity. The palate is medium to full-bodied, with polished tannins, and is supple and tasty and with great acidity and length. A balanced, elegant vintage, not showy or voluptuous, but more serious and developing complexity. A fine and elegant Ribera. Bravo! At this quality level this represents very good value.

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
